sections.narration: Welcome to our lesson on President Washington. First Administration (1789-1797). You'll experience this story through the eyes of Eleanor, age 14, living in New York City, 1789.

I'm Eleanor, fourteen, and I witnessed history today. George Washington took the oath of office as our first President on the balcony of Federal Hall in New York City. Thousands of people filled the streets, cheering and crying. Washington looked dignified but nervous—he knows the weight of this responsibility.
visuals: Chapter title: A New Government Begins
sections.key_takeaway: I'm Eleanor, fourteen, and I witnessed history today.

sections.narration: Secretary Hamilton proposed a bold financial plan. The national government should assume all state debts from the Revolutionary War. We should create a national bank. We should encourage manufacturing.
sections.key_takeaway: Secretary Hamilton proposed a bold financial plan.

sections.narration: In 1793, France and Britain went to war. France helped us win independence—shouldn't we help them now? But Washington declared neutrality. We're too weak for another war.
sections.key_takeaway: In 1793, France and Britain went to war.

sections.narration: In 1794, farmers in western Pennsylvania rebelled against Hamilton's whiskey tax. These frontier farmers grew grain and distilled it into whiskey—easier to transport than bulky grain sacks. The tax hit them hard, and they saw it as the same kind of unfair taxation Britain had imposed. The rebels attacked tax collectors, burned buildings, and threatened armed resistance.
sections.key_takeaway: In 1794, farmers in western Pennsylvania rebelled against Hamilton's whiskey tax.

sections.narration: When Washington left office in 1797, he'd served eight years as our first President. He could have served for life—many wanted him to. But he chose to step down, proving that American presidents would serve limited terms and transfer power peacefully. That decision may be his greatest gift to our republic.
sections.key_takeaway: When Washington left office in 1797, he'd served eight years as our first President.

sections.narration: In this lesson, we explored President Washington through 5 chapters. Key concepts included: George Washington (President), Cabinet, Alexander Hamilton, Thomas Jefferson.
